headings.heading: Are you completing this survey individually or collaborating with your team?

description: Questions associated with survey respondents taking the survey on behalf of their team.

Product Owner

headings.heading: What is your role in the team/ART?

title: Team Information

description: Questions based upon the SAFe DevOps Health Radar - Continuous Exploration Category: Hypothesize, Collaborate & Research, Architect and Synthesize

choices.text: Ideas are vague or not defined.
Ideas are defined (e.g., as epics) but do not include hypothesis statements.
Some ideas are expressed as hypothesis statements with measurable outcomes.
Most ideas are expressed as hypothesis statements with measurable outcomes and include an MVPs.
All ideas are expressed as hypothesis statements with measurable outcomes and include an MVPs.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to translate business ideas into clear and measurable epic hypothesis statements. (Hypothesize)

choices.text: Product Management roles and responsibilities are not defined or followed.
Product Management creates requirements in large batches with little customer or development collaboration.
Product Management collaborates with business or development experts, but not both, when defining requirements.
Product Management regularly collaborates with business, development, and operation experts but does not define Minimum Marketable Features.
Product Management always collaborates with business, development, and operation experts and defines Minimum Marketable Features.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to collaborate with customer and technology experts to define Minimum Marketable Features (MMF) in support of the hypothesis. (Collaborate & Research)

choices.text: Architecture is monolithic and fragile; it is difficult to change and involves managing complex dependencies across many components and systems.
Architecture is predominantly monolithic but some applications/systems are loosely coupled.
Architecture is most decoupled but doesn't allow Release on Demand.
Architecture is aligned around value delivery with few dependencies across components and systems.
Architecture is built for Release on Demand and operability.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's effectiveness at architecting for continuous delivery. (Architect)

choices.text: The program backlog does not exist or is not shared.
The program backlog exists, but the features are incomplete and prioritization is an afterthought.
The program backlog contains fully defined features, but are not prioritized using WSJF.
Features in the program backlog are complete, prioritized using WSJF and matched to the delivery capacity of the ART.
The program backlog is a collection of minimum marketable features created using BDD and prioritized using WSJF.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to synthesize the results of continuous exploration activities into a well-crafted, prioritized, actionable feature backlog. (Synthesize)

title: Continuous Exploration

description: Questions based upon the SAFe DevOps Health Radar Continuous Integration Category: Develop, Build, Test End-To-End and Stage

choices.text: The team backlog does not exist or is not used to manage daily work.
Stories are either incomplete or too verbose; unit tests are generally not written; peer reviews are not conducted.
Stories are complete; most changes have unit tests; peer reviews are usually conducted.
Code is checked in daily; unit test coverage is 80%+; peer reviews are always conducted.
Code is checked in multiple times per day; tests are written before code (BDD and TDD); pair work and other Built-in quality practices are the norm.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to quickly and reliably define and implement stories. (Develop)

choices.text: Builds are run fewer than once per iteration and/or are completely manual.
Builds are run once per iteration and are partially automated; dev branches are open for a month or more; builds break often.
Automated builds run once a day; broken builds are corrected in 2-4 hours; manual unit tests are run against each build; dev branches are open for 2-4 weeks.
Builds run automatically upon code commit; broken builds are corrected within 1 hour; automated unit tests are run against each build; dev branches are merged to trunk every iteration.

Builds run on every commit; builds include static code analysis and security testing; automated gated commits prevent defects from entering the version control; dev branches are merged to trunk on every commit.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's effectiveness at building and integrating continuously.

choices.text: Testing is performed manually in environments that do not mimic production; testing occurs in large batches during a scheduled 'testing' phase
Testing is performed manually in environments that do not mimic production; stories are implemented and tested manually within a single PI
Half of the testing is automated and performed in a production-like environment every PI
The majority of tests are automated and run in production-like environments; stories are implemented and fully tested every iteration
Successful builds trigger automatic deployment to production-like test environments; all tests are automated; tests run in parallel, and changes are fully validated after every commit

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's effectiveness at continuously testing, end-to-end, in a production-like environment.

choices.text: No staging environment exists or we use a test environment for staging.
Features are deployed manually to a staging environment once every PI.
Features are deployed to a staging environment once per month and demonstrated to Product Management.
Features and infrastructure are auto-deployed to a staging environment every iteration and accepted by Product Management.
Stories, changes and infrastructure are auto-deployed to a staging environment, and deployment is validated.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to deploy features in a staging environment. This is a production-like (non-test) environment for final validation prior to production deployment.

title: Continuous Integration

description: Questions based upon the SAFe DevOps Health Radar Continuous Deployment Category: Deploy, Verify, Monitor and Respond

choices.text: Features are deployed to production every 3+ months; deployments are manual and painful; 'deployed' means 'released'.
Features are deployed to production at PI boundaries; deployments are mostly manual; 'deployed' means 'released'.
Features are deployed to production every iteration; deployments are mostly automated; some features can be deployed without being released.
Features are deployed to production every iteration and fully automated through the continuous delivery pipeline; dark releases are common.

Features are deployed continuously throughout each iteration; Dev teams initiate deployments directly via continuous delivery pipeline tools; release is completely decoupled from deployment; dark releases are the norm.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to continuously deploy features to production as well as the ability to control their visibility using feature toggles and/or other means.

choices.text: Deployments are not verified in production before being released to end users.

Deployments are verified with manual smoke tests and/or UAT; we address deployment issues within a stated grace/warranty period; recovery is painful or impossible; we often correct issues directly in production.
Deployments are verified with manual tests prior to releasing to end users; recovey is painful; we do not make changes directly in production.
Deployments are verified using automated production tests, synthetic transactions and security tests prior to release; we can easily roll back or fix forward to recover from failed deployments.
Automated production tests run on an ongoing basis and feed monitoring systems; failed deployments can be rolled back instantly or fixed forward through the entire continuous delivery pipeline.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to accurately determine deployment success or failure.

choices.text: No feature level production monitoring exists; only infrastructure monitoring is in place.
Features only log faults and exceptions; analyzing events involves manually correlating logs from multiple systems.
Features log faults, user activity and other events; data is analyzed manually to investigate incidents and measure business value of features.
Full-stack monitoring is in place; events is automtically correlated throughout the architecture; data is presented through system-specific dashboards.
Federated monitoring platform provides one-stop access to full-stack insights; data is used to gauge system performance.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's effectiveness at monitoring the full solution stack (front-end, middle tier, back-end, infrastructure, etc.).

choices.text: Customers find issues before we do; resolving high priority issues is time consuming and reactive; customers have low confidence in our ability to recover from production issues.
Operations owns production issues; development involvement requires significant escalation; teams blame each other in times of crisis.
Development and operations collectively own the incident resolution process; recovering from major incidents is reactive, but a team effort.
Our monitoring systems detect most issues before our customers do; development and operations work proactively to recover from major incidents.

Our monitoring systems alert us to potential problems based on carefully-designed tolerance thresholds; Developers are responsible for supporting their own code and proactively issue fixes through the continuous delivery pipeline before users are affected.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's effectiveness at proactively detecting production issues, and quickly resolving them.

title: Continuous Deployment

description: Questions based upon the SAFe DevOps Health Radar Release on Demand Category: Release, Stabilize, Measure and Learn

choices.text: Releases are coupled to deployments and customers are extremely dissatisfied with the frequency of releases.
Releases are coupled to deployments, but customers are somewhat dissatisfied with the frequency of releases.
Release and deployment are coupled, but both occur continuously or on demand.
Release is decoupled from deployment; deployed features are released based on business demnad.
Deployed features can be released to a subset of the user population; code is refactored to remove featue toggles when no longer used.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to release features to users on demand.

choices.text: We experience frequent unplanned outages and/or security breaches with long recovery times.
We experience occasional unplanned outages, but recover within our service level agreements.
We have very few unplanned outages; availability, security, and disaster recovery measures are effective, and are better then our service level agreements.
We have no unplanned outages; We plan and rehearse failure and recovery.
We maximize resiliency by deliberately injecting faults into our production environment and rehearsing recovery procedures.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's effectiveness at maintaining stable solutions that avoid unplanned down time and security breaches.

choices.text: We don’t define or measure the value of features.
We’ve defined what ‘value’ is but don’t know how to measure it.
We capture qualitative feedback from the business about the value of our features.
We capture qualitative and quantitative feedback from the business and our monitoring systems about the value of our features.
We aggregate the quantitative and qualitative feedback to objectively validate the original hypothesis.

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to collect objective data about the actual value realized by deployed features.

choices.text: Features are never evaluated post-release.
Features are sometimes evaluated using subjective information.
Hypotheses are evaluated using objective measures, but actions are heavily influenced by corporate politics.
Hypotheses are objectively evaluated; pivot or persevere decisions are made without mercy or guilt.
Continuous learning and experimentation are ingrained in the culture of the organization."

headings.heading: Rate your team's/ART's ability to make 'pivot-or-persevere' decisions based on empirical performance data, and commitment to actively applying those insights to continuously improve the delivery pipeline.

title: Release on Demand
